title: How to celebrate the Fourth of July in Sydney
text:
IT’S one of the biggest celebrations of the year in the US, but there are still plenty of ways y’all can enjoy a slice of American culture in Sydney — both on Independence Day, celebrated on July 4, and throughout the rest of the year.
From catching a gridiron game to a night at the drive-in or a burger or hot dog at one of the many American-style diners which have popped up around town, here are some to consider.
FOOD FUN
Steph Veljaca enjoys burgers and milkshakes at Skyline Drive In Diner. Picture: Justin Sanson Source: News Limited
Skyline Drive In and Diner, Blacktown
For anyone who grew up watching Happy Days — or its multiple re-runs — this 1960s-esque diner at Skyline Drive In at Blacktown is about as American as it gets.
The retro diner serves chilli dogs, hot dogs, burgers, malt shakes, spiders and banana splits, which can be eaten in, in your car or under the stars in one of the Grass Class deck chairs. With the opening of Terminator: Genisys this week, it’s the perfect time to check it out.
Grown-ups can also pop next door to check out the huge selection of American whiskey at Atura’s Roadhouse Bar & Grill, which is the perfect accompaniment to the hotel’s Roadhouse Burger with bourbon-infused sauce.
Cricketers Arms Rd, Blacktown; gates open 5.30pm, first session 7pm, diner open to Skyline
Drive In patrons from 5.30pm daily, 9622 4170, eventcinemas.com.au /cinema/drive-in-blacktown
The Soda Factory, Surry Hills
American-style diner, The Soda Factory is throwing a big party to celebrate Independence Day, with the Surry Hills venue decorated with red, white and blue and serving a burger made with two deep fried mac and cheese patties as buns and a pickle on top.
Channeling the red, white an blue vibe is a special cocktail The Abraham Bindrinkin, with blue curacao, vodka, ginger beer and a cherry on top.
16A Wentworth Ave, Surry Hills; from 5pm, 8096 9120, sodafactory.com.au
The American-style burger made with two deep fried mac and cheese patties as buns at Soda Factory. Picture: John Fotiadis Source: News Corp Australia
The Oxford Tavern
Every Sunday is like the Fourth of July at this popular pub, where you can gorge on American smoked meats including pulled pork, brisket and ribs at the Black Betty barbecue.
Chefs start cooking the meat the day before so it is ready to be served in the barbecue corner of the beer garden by noon — 18 hours after being placed in Black Betty, the venue’s house made double chamber, 4x44 gallon drum smoker. The meat is sold in 100g lots with slaw and a roll. This weekend, there’s also an Independence Day special — smoked turkey wings with Alabama white BBQ sauce.
1 New Canterbury Rd, Petersham; Saturday and Sunday from noon until sold out, 8019 9351, theoxfordtavern.com.au
Smoked meat at Black Betty at The Oxford Tavern in Petersham. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Keg & Brew and Dove & Olive, Surry Hills
These popular inner-city pubs will be offering a special American menu all day, with $12 hot dogs and fries including a Chilli Dog with Frankfurter, jalapens, chilli con-carne, salsa picante and chilli mayo.
Sierra Nevada and Sydney Brewery Rye IPA will be available on tap, and the Keg & Brew will have a special bourbon cocktail pitcher with gin, lime juice and bitters topped with ginger ale garnished with maraschino cherries for $15.
The Dove & Olive will also offer Buffalo hot kickin’ wings with American-style blue vein cheese dip; a double cheese burger with double candy bacon; and New York cheese cake with mojito strawberries, double cream and orange exlir. A hot dog eating competition will run from 3pm-4pm where contestants will try to eat 10 hot dogs in three minutes.
Keg & Brew, 26 Foveaux St, Surry Hills, daily 10am-late,
9212 1740, kegandbrew.com.au/fourthjuly;
Dove & Olive, 156 Devonshire St, Surry Hills, open 10am-midnight, 9699 6001, doveandolive.com.au/fourthjuly
Hot dogs at the Dove and Olive in Surry Hills. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Owner of Brooklyn Boy Bagels Michaal Shaffran. Picture: Supplied Source: News Limited
Brooklyn Boy Bagels, Matraville
For a taste of New York, head to this uber cool bagel shop for Sloppy Joe bagels (made with ground beef, onions and sauce), pastrami, reuben and corned-beef sandwiches.
Sweet tooths will be treated to S’mores (marshmallow and chocolate on housemade Graham crackers), New York egg creams with Hersheys chocolate syrup and Challah French toast with an all-American playlist in the background.
448 Bunnerong Rd, Matraville; 8540 4595, brooklynboy.com.au
SoCal
This California-themed bar will have hot wings and hot dogs on special all day as well as $6 Fireball shots. There are also Cali-inspired share plates, tacos, quesadillas and ceviche created by head chef Zac Smart, a wine list with a focus on the Californian region and an extensive selection of American craft beers and cocktails with a slant towards tequila.
1 Young St, Neutral Bay; noon-2am, 9904 5691, socalsydney.com.au
SoCal in Neutral Bay. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Miss Peaches Soul Food Kitchen
Sip on craft beer from the biggest US beer list in Australia while knocking down the Liberty burger with Freedom fries and listening to American folk and bluegrass from Ross Tipper and country-flavoured rockabilly from Cruisin’ Deuces.
Batch Brewing Co. and Archie Rose distillery (The 1st distillery in Sydney in 150 years) are also collaborating to create a beer distilled from whiskey, launching on the night.
201 Missenden Rd, Newtown; from 5pm, 9557 7280, misspeaches.com.au
Shrimp Po'boy from Miss Peaches at the Marlborough Hotel in Newtown. Picture: Supplied Source: News Corp Australia
Ja zz City BBQ
With the black formica chrome-edge tables and classic jazz video screens fitted into each black leather booth, you feel like you are in the US at this authentic Texas BBQ. Meals include beef brisket, pork and beef ribs, sausages, pulled pork and turkey, sold by weight, with sides such as beans, coleslaw, potato salad and cornbread. Desserts can include pecan pie, key lime pie, strawberry pie, buttermilk pie or raisin pie.
200 Goulburn St, Surry Hills; 9264-2572, jazzcitydiner.com/bbq
SPORT
Ice hockey
Nothing quite compares to the atmosphere and excitement of a fast-paced ice hockey game in North America. You can join the fun by watching the teams from The Sydney Bears ice hockey club compete — or learn to play yourself. The club caters for recreational players in its junior and senior divisions, and also focuses on the development and training of new players, regardless of age, skill or gender.
The Sydney Bears, Macquarie Ice Rink, cnr Waterloo and Herring Rds, North Ryde; sydneybears.com.au
Sydney Bears ice-hockey goalie Matt Salisbury at Allphones Arena Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
G ridiron
There have been countless Hollywood movies made about this American football game, and the sport is growing in popularity in Australia. Gridiron NSW has two divisions; Division One (also known as Senior Football or Over 18s) and Colts Division (also known as Juniors Football or Under 18s). Division One season runs from September to December and Colts Division runs from February to April. Players across the league are selected to form the NSW Wolfpack team (Seniors) and NSW Wolverines team (Colts) which plays in the Gridiron Australia National Championships.
To find out how to join a club or where to see a game see gridironnsw.org.au or like Gridiron NSW on Facebook
Bondi Raiders play in the Women's Gridiron Competition. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Baseball
Head to Blacktown to see professional team the Sydney Blue Sox compete against interstate teams on Thursday nights, Friday nights, Saturdays and Sundays from October to January. Imports from US teams such as the Arizona Diamond Backs and Detroit Tigers will also be on the field. Or you can find your nearest Little League club and join in the action yourself.
Blue Sox Stadium, Blacktown International Sportspark, Eastern Rd, Rooty Hill, 9675 6872, nsw.baseball.com.au
Trent Oeltjen from the Sydney Blue Sox in action. Picture: Joe Vella/SMP Images/ABL Media Source: Supplied
Stars + Stripes: American Art of the 21st Century exhibition at Manly Art Gallery in July. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Stars + Stripes exhibition, Manly Art Gallery
A major free exhibition of American contemporary art will open at Manly Art Gallery and Museum today.
Stars + Stripes: American Art of the 21st Century from the Goldberg Collection features 52 works by 31 contemporary US artists drawn from the private collection of Sydney-based Lisa and Danny Goldberg.
They include installation, drawing, photography and sculpture. It is the first major exhibition of contemporary American art to tour Australia since New York’s Museum of Modern Art toured Two Decades of American Painting in 1967, introducing Australian audiences to the work of a new generation of American artists including Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg.
After its Manly showing the exhibition will continue to tour to eight regional areas including Grafton, Cowra, Taree and Wagga Wagga in NSW throughout 2016.
West Esplanade Reserve, Manly; open July 4-August 30, Tuesday-Sunday, 10am-5pm, 9976 1421, manly.nsw.gov.au/attractions/gallery/
